question.title: All hand cursors look the same in JavaFX
question.body:
This is my test code:

public class CursorTest extends Application {

    @Override
    public void start(Stage primaryStage) {

        VBox dndBox = new VBox(new Label("DragAndDrop"));
        dndBox.setPrefSize(100, 100);
        dndBox.setStyle("-fx-background-color: yellow");
        dndBox.setOnDragDetected(event -> {
            Dragboard db = dndBox.startDragAndDrop(TransferMode.COPY);
            ClipboardContent content = new ClipboardContent();
            content.putString("test");
            db.setContent(content);
            event.consume();
        });

        VBox handBox = createColoredBox(Color.LIGHTBLUE, Cursor.HAND);
        VBox closedHandBox = createColoredBox(Color.LIGHTCORAL, Cursor.CLOSED_HAND);
        VBox openHandBox = createColoredBox(Color.LIGHTGREEN, Cursor.OPEN_HAND);

        VBox root = new VBox(10, dndBox, handBox, closedHandBox, openHandBox);

        Scene scene = new Scene(root, 320, 350);
        primaryStage.setTitle("Cursor Test");
        primaryStage.setScene(scene);
        primaryStage.show();
    }

    private VBox createColoredBox(Color color, Cursor cursor) {
        VBox box = new VBox(new Label(cursor.toString()));
        box.setPrefSize(100, 100);
        box.setStyle(String.format("-fx-background-color: #%s;", color.toString().substring(2, 8)));
        box.setCursor(cursor);
        return box;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }
}

and this is the result:

As you can see, when I perform drag and drop, the cursor changes to a closed hand. However, when I move the mouse over the other three VBoxes, the cursor remains the same. Can anyone tell me how to make the cursor a closed hand when hovering over a VBox without drag and drop?

I use JavaFX 25-ea+20 and Ubuntu 20.04.6 LTS.

question_comments.body: Try an ImageCursor. "A custom image representation of the mouse cursor. On platforms that don't support custom cursors, Cursor.DEFAULT will be used in place of the specified ImageCursor.". It might or might not work on your platform. You can try to choose the best cursor. Read the javadoc for caveats (which are many).
Do you see correct cursors if you use JavaFX 24?  (I should mention that on my Debian system, HAND and CLOSED_HAND are identical, but OPEN_HAND is different from them.)

This only works with the JavaFX app being frontmost app. When floating over JavaFX app that is not frontmost, I see only the usual arrow pointer. Furthermore, when clicking to bring the JavafX app to front, the mouse pointer remains an arrow. The mouser pointer is not updated until moving across boundary of boxes (updated on entering).

FYI, I am seeing on macOS what I presume is proper behavior. First box presents an arrow pointer when floating, and an arrow-with-document pointer when dragging — apparently a host-OS determined appearance as mentioned by Slaw. The 2nd box "HAND" has a hand-in-glove with pointing finger. The third has hand-in-glove with no fingers pointing. The last box has hand-in-glove with all five fingers extended.  Versions…  Java Runtime.version: 24.0.1+9-FR OpenJFX version: 24.0.2-ea+1 os.name Mac OS X os.version 15.5

Though it may not be a bug per se. It could just be that your system doesn't have cursors for "open hand" and "closed hand". If you look at the native code, you'll see JavaFX falls back to the same value as Cursor.HAND if gdk_cursor_new_from_name returns null for OPEN_HAND or CLOSED_HAND.

The cursor during drag-and-drop seems to be controlled by the OS based on whether or not the application under the cursor will accept the drop. As for the "hand cursors" all looking the same, I can't reproduce that on Windows 11. You may have found (another) bug.
